description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - policy, planning and administration

Removing key barriers to the widespread commercialization of energy efficient domestic appliances, such as refrigerators, lighting products and air-conditioners as well as electric motors. PIMS_3087_CC_FSP.
Energy Efficiency Standards and Labels in Colombia (S&L Colombia)
To reduce CO2 emissions through the implementation of a (mandatory) energy efficiency standards and labels program
a) Change in annual sales towards average higher efficiency appliances (lower unit energy consumption, UEC)

comment.narrative: According to unit energy consumption (UEC) table in Prodoc

Reduction in average UEC (see table in Prodoc) of selected household appliances (refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers and freezers, lamps, ballasts, water heaters, air conditioning equipment, and washing machines) and electric motors
According to the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the Regulations will be issued during 2015.

description.narrative: b) Share of non-compliant products in mandatory S&L

comment.narrative: N/A (there is no mandatory S&L)
Measured as part of surveys of component 2 at the end of the project

The issuance of the Technical Regulations (RETIQ) on standardization and labelling for energy end-use equipment has been delayed for reasons beyond the control of the project and the executing agency, preventing us from measuring the progress on this indicator. This indicator shall be measured at the end of the project.
Annual energy demand will increase to about 80 TWh by 2020

With URE (Government\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\'s policy on rational use of energy), annual power demand in Colombia is expected to stabilize at around 50 TWh, implying savings of 30 TWh, out of which 6.7 TWh of savings can be attributed to the use of more EE appliances.
Of the 6.7 TWh savings, 60% (4 TWh) is expected due to the direct and indirect impact of this project ´s intervention

UPME performs an energy balance every year in various sectors. The adjusted figure for energy consumption was 57,614 GWh in 2013. Residential 21,293 GWh, industrial 19,685 GWh, commercial 14,830 GWh, and other 1,806. The energy balance will not be the only tool used to monitor this indicator; it shall be supplemented by a strategy to measure the specific impact of equipment labelling. However, it is important to note that equipment labelling has no impact on the country's energy consumption as the Technical Regulations are yet to be issued. This indicator will be monitored once the Technical Regulations are released.

description.narrative: d) Amount of CO2 avoided (in comparison with baseline level)

comment.narrative: CO2 emissions will rise in accordance with energy consumption (see project objective indicator c)

Direct emissions reduction (cumulative over period 2011-2015):1,309 ktCO2
Indirect emissions reduction (cumulative 2016-2025): 9,511 ktCO2
Annual energy savings due to EE appliances 11.4 TWh 2025 (of which 60% can be attributed to the project)

The estimate for total reduction by the year 2025 is about 4 million tons of CO2, which amounts to 66% of total emissions due to energy consumption in the residential and commercial sectors in Colombia. This reduction, which corresponds to nearly 2% of the total emissions of the energy industry according to the National Emissions Inventory (INGEI), will be mainly achieved through the implementation of the Regulations in commercial and domestic refrigeration equipment, gas heaters, gas appliances, and air conditioning equipment. This baseline is defined in the study that the project conducted during the reporting period, "Current Market Structure" (May 2015). This evaluation established that the implementation of the RETIQ brings an environmental benefit to society and promotes the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the period defined by the study, 2015-2025, compared to a scenario without RETIQ. This reduction is mainly due to the energy consumption related to energy end-use equipment.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacities of key public and private agencies
e) Status of programs in key public agencies to implement effective mandatory S&L

comment.narrative: Insufficient implementation of S&L program which is voluntary only
New policy provisions and compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted for mandatory S&L that reflect international € œbest practices

This project contributed to the implementation of energy efficiency measures, identified through 19 regional workshops (163 people) and 2 virtual workshops (53 people), amounting to a total of 216 officials trained during this year, giving a boost to the growth of the institutional capacity to meet the labelling requirements once the Regulations come into effect. Moreover, the training modules that were carried out as part of the project (February 2015) have been included by the SENA, as a strategic ally, as inputs for the curricular design of the training course “Energy Efficiency Labelling." The modules have been very important for training and will continue to take place throughout 2015-2016. Additionally, the project made a diagnosis of the National Quality Subsystem (SNCA), the instance for promoting markets through quality and productivity, by coordinating activities between public and private organizations for the standardization, technical regulations, accreditation, compliance and metrology assessment. In this way, we identified the strengths and weaknesses of these organizations for the implementation of the Regulations. The suggested Regulations were disclosed in 2 meetings with the SNCA entities, with the attendance of 28 public officials. There was an assessment on the capacity of the country's laboratories to meet the demand for testing once the Regulations are issued, concluding that the country has a group of laboratories competent enough in the short-term to carry out energy efficiency tests on refrigerators (7 laboratories) and gas appliances (7 laboratories). Currently, there are not any laboratories that can perform tests on washing machines, but it was found that there are 2 laboratories with a high potential for carrying out the aforementioned tests or trials in the short-term. As for air conditioners, there is only one laboratory with a high potential for carrying out the tests. These conclusions, and other related to the demand for future testing once the Regulations are issued, are included in the study, which significantly contributed to the strategic lines in order to strengthen not only the network of laboratories in the country, but also the SNCA as a whole.
These results were made public through 3 workshops for 107 people. Additionally, the project took part in the World Metrology Day with a presentation about Labelling Regulations and their relationship with the SNCA and metrology (May 20th 2015). 50 people attended this workshop.

description.narrative: Consolidated information on the market structure and established market transformation strategy with defined instruments and procedures
f) Level of information available to define energy consumption in label categories and for measuring project impact

comment.narrative: Data available at UPME\'s database, but needs to be updated and expanded (CM: YA SE TIENE LA LINEA BASE?)
Upgraded database and regularly updated data on annual sale of different appliances per energy classes (A to G) available for public use (with finalized market monitoring methodology)

The information on the structure of the national market for equipment subject to the RETIQ project was updated and consolidated. There was also an assessment of the behaviour of the market in the face of the inclusion of mandatory labelling of energy efficiency parameters (May 2015). The study considered variables such as existing equipment and equipment currently being used in Colombian households, replaced equipment, produced equipment, imported equipment, exported equipment, equipment sales, annual energy consumption associated to existing equipment, equipment prices. Thus, the National Government has a diagnosis of the current market and its analysis on projected sales through a model that determined the impact the RETIQ would have if it comes into effect. This study has made a great contribution to the country by providing a current picture of market behaviour and an in-depth analysis on the areas that must be strengthened in order to achieve a positive transformation of the market, where energy efficiency is considered as a variable in purchasing decisions. One of the main conclusions of the study is the need to work and direct efforts toward training the sales force, who directly influence purchasing decisions of Colombian consumers. Their current training and information level is very poor; there is work being done alongside the industry (ANDI) to start providing this training to the sales staff of companies.

description.narrative: g) Status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability (transformation strategy)

comment.narrative: S&L system in place is voluntary, but has limited impact so far

Market transformation strategy enhanced for implementation of mandatory S&L (programs, procedures and organizational arrangements, including testing and enforcement) with a budgeted implementation plan

There have been 12 inter-institutional meetings (Ministry of Commerce, Ministry of Environment, Superintendence of Industry and Commerce, SENA, Confecámaras, ANDI, FENALCO, Asodelco, ANDESCO, ACAIRE, Corpotrece). Additionally, there was 1 workshop to disclose the results of the study on the current market for equipment (37 participants). The purpose of this workshop was to follow up on the commitment of public and private authorities regarding the implementation of the Regulations as part of a comprehensive strategy for institutional sustainability. As a result of these meetings, each entity took ownership of the labelling process and a communication strategy for Labelling in Colombia was established, bringing together the efforts made by various public and private entities on the subject.

description.narrative: Strengthened legal framework for mandatory S&L and endorsed final Technical Regulations
h) Status of decision-making regarding introduction of mandatory EE S&L

comment.narrative: Mandatory MEPS exist for CFLs; voluntary labels and MEPS for ballasts, cloth washers, fluorescent lamps, refrigerators and freezers, air conditioners and electric water heaters

Decree(s) signed on Technical regulations making labels (and/or MEPs) mandatory for electric motors and household appliances (in the following order of priority: refrigerators and freezers, lighting, ballasts, room air conditioners, water heaters and washing machines)

Institutional strengthening, the issuance of the regulations, and the support to their implementation are sustainability standards. As a result, the Ministry of Mines and Energy, the Ministry of Commerce, and the Ministry of Environment are committed and will work together so that both the Technical Regulations and the associated processes are established as a national guideline for disseminating this policy.

description.narrative: Consumer and industry engagement strategy developed and implemented
i) Priority of different criteria used by customers in their purchasing decision

comment.narrative: No emphasis among the consumers (and sales personnel) on energy efficiency aspects and life cycle costs when purchasing and marketing new appliances
Beside the initial purchasing price, energy efficiency and life-cycle costs have become a key criteria for purchasing decisions, guided by the energy label

The project still has its web page (currently at www.etiquetaenergetica.gov.co, now integrated to UPME's server) with the purpose of providing information related to the energy label. The web page is expected to help end consumers understand how their purchasing decisions influence energy consumption and climate change. The page also contains, with access to the general public, Training Modules (4 Modules), an educational and learning support material developed by the project (February 2015). These modules also serve as input for SENA in formulating curricular plans for nationwide implementation through on-site or online courses The web page currently shows an increase of 73% in the number of new users. Moreover, the project designed a communication strategy to support the dissemination and promotion of labelling, which included the participation of 14 strategic allies. This strategy cross-sectionally supports every component of the project in order to establish mutually beneficial relations with public and private actors, toward the dissemination of information regarding labelling. This is done by providing new communication settings and channels, different from those obtained through procurement, as well as generating public opinion and a discussion on the subject of the project, and gathering materials or contents that support or reinforce the messages already designed. In this way, the strategic allies (ANDI, FENALCO, Ministry of Commerce, Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Mines and Energy, Confecámaras, Andesco, Asodelco, Corpotrece, SENA, SIC, ONAC, INM, ICONTEC) are committed to supporting the activities for training, dissemination, advertising, and generation of content through their own channels. This aims at the appropriation and adequate response to the matter from a communication approach that can have regional and national impact.

description.narrative: Monitoring and evaluation the for project and EE S&L program carried out
j) The level of information available for monitoring and evaluation and adaptive management

comment.narrative: N/A
Adequate information available for monitoring & evaluation and for measuring project results

The project has an operating and decision-making structure that allows us to disseminate information and results through different means. Decision-making tasks are the responsibility of the Steering Committee, which meets twice a year (11.26.14 – 05.19.15) to discuss and approve project activities. Additionally, a follow-up meeting is held quarterly with UNDP and the executing agency. This allows continuous monitoring of project activities. In addition, the project Coordination Unit carries out a daily follow-up of all activities. This year, the first Project Financial Audit (February 2015) took place, which resulted in a Low Risk Rating, given that the project management has properly strengthened its administrative procedures, processes, and policies.

Development of National Capacity for the Environmentally Sound Management and Disposal of Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs).

title.narrative: Desarrollo de la Capacidad para la Gestión y Eliminación Ambientalmente Adecuada de PCB

description.narrative: Desarrollo de la capacidad para la gestión y eliminación ambientalmente adecuada de PCBs (Bifenilos policlorados)
To protect human health and the environment locally as well as globally arising from unsound PCB management in Colombia
Quantity of PCBs (liquids and solids) destroyed in the project period (2013-2017).

comment.narrative: 1000 MT PCBs destroyed pre- project through exports.
Additional minimum of 600 MT of PCBs (liquids and solids) disposed of in an environmentally sound manner.

To this date the project has resulted in the elimination of 451.1 MT (75.2% of the target). Of this quantity, during the 2014-2015 reporting period 104.1 MT was exported for disposal. In addition, during this reporting period 47 MT of non porous solid waste contaminated with PCBs were treated by using washing processes.

description.narrative: Quantity (tonnes) of equipment and waste contaminated by PCBs, that is stockpiled by the year immediately preceding the closure of the Colombia PCB inventory.

comment.narrative: 400 MT PCB stockpiled
All known PCBs safely stockpiled.
According to national inventory reports, 585 MT of waste was stored. From the total, 534,3 MT of waste are in the owners and 50,8 in authorized facilities.

description.narrative: Persons from environmental, health, and comercial authorities, trained and qualified in PCB management.

comment.narrative: Environmental, health and commerce authorities personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB stockpiles in the country.
50 officials of the environmental, health and commerce authorities trained to control the commerce, storage, transport, treatment and final disposal of PCBs.

Of a total of 13 workshops held since the project’s start, 6 workshops were held during the reporting period 2014 to 2015 during which 6 environmental authorities and 5 foreign trade authorities were trained.
Of a total of 210 cumulative participants, 93 participants were trained during the current reporting period.
This number of participants is equal to 4 times the project target.
Training workshops addressed technical aspects and regulations on storage, transportation and proper PCB environmental disposal.

description.narrative: One (1) norm elaborated for thermal treatment

comment.narrative: Since 2013, the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development is elaborating a norm which regulates the thermal treatment of dangerous waste and requires that specific studies be elaborated to establish the treatment of other waste that is considered extremely toxic such as PCBs.
One (1) norm approved for thermal treatment.
A draft of the regulation of thermal treatment of hazardous waste was developed for the Ministry of Environment, whom should include in its text PCB burn tests results.

description.narrative: Number of guidelines / manuals established for PCB management.

comment.narrative: In 2011, Colombia released the Resolution 222, through which the management and PCB elimination goals are managed in accordance to the requirements. This norm requires that PCB owners, and equipment which contains PCBs that is in use or disuse, be marked. Different methodologies have been developed at the national level to carry out PCB equipment marking, and these methodologies must be compiled into a report. The norm establishes measures for the adequate maintenance of the equipment and the avoidance of cross-contamination.
4 guidelines / manuals developed by end of the project

description.narrative: The indicator will measure how many demonstration projects have been developed within the project framework to treat or eliminate equipment and waste with PCBs in Colombia.

comment.narrative: The country has no facilities for treatment or disposal of PCBs.
At least two treatment and disposal alternatives in demonstrative pilot projects servicing PCB owners.

In December 2014 the pilot project of installation and operation of the washing plant for equipment contaminated with PCB was completed. The project was funded through a Partnership Agreement signed between project and LITO S.A.S.
9 units contaminated with PCB with concentrations ranging from 58 ppm to 85.000 ppm PCB were washed.
In addition, as part of the agreements signed between the project and CEMEX COLOMBIA S.A and TECNIAMSA S.A., evaluations and ratings were completed and were selected the best two (2) facilities to conduct PCB burn tests, one test burn for each company.
Industrial safety evaluations were conducted to prepare test protocols and a company was hired to prepare the strategic communication management process to communities located near CEMEX facilities.
During the period 2014-2015 the project prepared a project to finance the installation of a facility at semi-industrial scale for demonstrating the elimination of PCB.

description.narrative: Number of companies implementing new regulatory guidelines

comment.narrative: A new PCB management base regulation has been passed. No new guidelines PCB holders or service providers are in compliance with new guidelines
15 maintenance companies operating according to new guidelines.

As of June 30, 2015 a document summarizing best practices for maintenance activities, is available.
It includes an assessment of the operations and good practices from 20 companies (133% of the project target).
All 20 companies participated in the preparation of these documents.

description.narrative: Number of operators, technicians, and professionals trained in the adequate management of PCBs.

comment.narrative: Training and capacity building is required for personnel who work for businesses involved in PCB management and for those in the electricity sector who have waste equipment with PCBs, so that they may carry out their work in accordance with national and international standards.
50 maintenance and other personnel at PCB holders trained in safe PCB handling.

During the second half of 2015, under the framework of GRANT with CIDET, three (3) validation workshops related to the compilation of good maintenance practices were held, 70 people attended these workshops representing about 20 companies engaged in these activities.

description.narrative: Number of businesses that provide transportation, storage, or elimination of PCBs in accordance with national and international standards.

comment.narrative: Currently there are six businesses in the country who provide storage and transportation services for PCBs; there are none who carry out PCB elimination. The businesses involved with PCB elimination must comply with national norms and international standards.
6 Service providers (storage, packing and transport) operating according to new guidelines.

Three (3) service providers have been evaluated against the standards for storage, packaging and transport of PCBs.
Currently only one (1) company has three (3) secure warehouses that can operate according to standards.

description.narrative: Strengthening the legal, administrative and regulatory framework for the sound management of PCBs.
A norm for dangerous waste management which includes PCB treatment.

comment.narrative: There has been a new regulation (Resolution 222) for the PCB Management in Colombia that needs to be implemented. There is not a norm that regulates the treatment and elimination of PCB wastes.
A legally binding norm or technical regulation for the treatment of PCBs issued.

A draft of amendment of the PCBs regulation (Resolution 222) was formulated and put into public consultation during this reporting period.
The Ministry of Environment continues, by consulting national and international experts, the process of issuing the Regulation for Thermal Treatment of Hazardous Waste.
The Ministry will incorporate the results of the PCB burn tests, in particular technical and safety requirements.
This regulation is expected to be completed and in public consult by 2016.

description.narrative: Personnel from the environmental, health and customs authorities are trained for the implementation of the existing norms issued for PCB management, including controlling PCBs in body fluids and food and import control system for electrical equipment (transformers, capacitors) and dielectric oils

comment.narrative: The Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development in December 2011, issued a guideline on the management of PCBs, which has established a number of responsibilities for generators of this waste.
Eight workshops or training sessions with officials from the environmental authorities to present the existing norm and the norm or regulation for PCB treatment.

Up to June 20, 2015 11 workshops only for environmental authorities were conducted (137% of the target), 4 were held during 2014-2015 period (24 officials of environmental authorities were trained during the current reporting period).
The workshops included the main aspects of the regulations governing the management of PCB (Resolution 222 of 2011).
It is expected that through this training approach, authorities will become aware of the technical and management aspects involved in PCB management.

description.narrative: Guidelines or a document which orient the work of health authorities in controlling population exposure to PCBs.

comment.narrative: The health authorities have no programme established to evaluate PCB incidence in impacted populations.
Guidelines for the health authorities to formulate controls for PCB exposure have been established

As of June 30, 2015 there is a signed agreement with the National Institute of Health (NIH) for the development of epidemiological surveillance protocols and their application during next period (2015- 2016), for a sample group of people potentially exposed to PCB.
The health authorities have no programme established to evaluate PCB incidence in impacted populations.
One workshop with the health authorities related to the human exposure of these substances delivered.
The workshop will be developed by the National Institute of Health (NIH), under the agreement signed during the second half of 2015.

description.narrative: Guidelines or a document which orient the work of commerce authorities in the control of importation and exportation of equipment and waste with PCBs.

comment.narrative: There is no existing protocol for the control of importing and exporting of PCB contaminated equipment and waste at the ports and border crossings
Guideline or instrument published so that the customs authorities, the police and other commercial authorities can control the importation and exportation of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes.

A draft document “Guidelines for the Control of Import/Export of PCB contaminated Equipment and Waste” aimed at foreign trade authorities is available. It is currently under going its validation by relevant authorities.
There was also a process with foreign trade authorities for the characterization of control processes implemented the last four years in imports related to transformers that may contain PCB. .
Three workshops to present and distribute the guidelines or instrument for the control of imports of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes completed.

Up to June 30, 2015 there have been two (2) workshops (67% of the goal) aimed at foreign trade authorities, with a total of 89 attendees from six national authorities.
These workshops have included aspects related to the transboundary movement procedures for PCBs (Basel Convention), safety and health aspects in activities related to PCB handling and management alternatives in Colombia.

description.narrative: Economic or financial instrument evaluated for the promotion of PCB management.

comment.narrative:
There are fiscal exceptions for investments in PCB environmentally sound management.
There are credit lines available with non-refundable funding for companies that invest in issues such as quality control and environmental management.
Evaluation of feasibility of applying economic, financial or market instruments to promote environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs completed.
100% of the target was achieved. The final report, analyzing the feasibility and implementation of economic instruments related to PCB management activities, has been published.

description.narrative: Labeling strategy for the identification of PCBs in equipment (in use and out of use) implemented in companies in the electricity sector.

comment.narrative: The Colombian norm for PCB management establishes that the equipment that could have PCBs (transformers and capacitors) should be identified and labeled. Currently only a limited number of equipment have been labeled regarding PCB content.
Development of a demonstration project with the equipment owners that have PCBs for the labeling of equipment using the different available alternatives.

During the reporting period 2014 – 2015, a project for the identification and marking of PCB equipment owned companies that provide services in a not interconnected Zone, was prepared and financed by the project through a GRANT developed by CIDET.
Currently 15 companies in the power sector are working on activities to identify and mark PCB containing equipment.
During the reporting period the project finished a guidance document summarizing available alternatives for marking equipment.
All tested equipment should be labeled by the end of the project.

Currently companies from the electric sector are working on equipment marking tasks to meet the requirements of the current regulation, which states that at least 30% of PCB containing equipment should be marked by 2016.

description.narrative: Development of national capacity for environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs.
Information system operating to consolidate, disseminate and update in an orderly and periodic manner the data related to the inventory and management of PCBs in the country.

comment.narrative: The IDEAM has a tool to register and update the inventory of the amount of PCBs eliminated. The PCB generators must keep the information up to date using electronic means.
Information platform to manage PCBs established and updated.

With financial support provided by the project, maintenance and strengthening of the National PCB Inventory and information system continues, lead by IDEAM.
As of April 30, 2015, the PCB information system showed that: 840 owners of equipment and waste are registered and active. These owners have reported about 430.000 pieces of PCB containing equipment containing dielectric oil.
Of these 840 owners, 138 were registered during this reporting period 2014-2015.

description.narrative: Number of (public and private) laboratories strengthened for sampling and analysis of PCBs and other persistent pollutants in different matrices (oil, water, soil, air, food, blood and breast milk).

comment.narrative: There are approximately 10 private laboratories that have PCB analysis capacity as well as the laboratories from the Universities and research centers that can be strengthened for PCB analysis (Universidad de Antioquia, Universidad National, Universidad del Valle and the Universidad de Cartagena).
A program of technical assistance for 10 laboratories to validate the analytical methods to identify PCBs in different matrices has been developed.

During the reporting period the project has performed a Intercalibration exercise between national laboratories.
Currently 20 laboratories (200% of the target) have participated in activities of technical assistance funded by the project.
There are 3 accredited laboratories for measuring of PCBs in water and dielectric oils. There are laboratories that have the equipment to analyze PCBs and some are doing so.
An exercise of intercalibration developed with at least 10 private or public laboratories including IDEAM in Colombia, in the issue of PCB quantification in different matrices.

The intercalibration exercise took place during the period 2014-2015 and included the participation of 20 laboratories (200% of the target). The intercalibration exercise concluded that 18 participating laboratories have a highly satisfactory level to measure PCB in dielectrics oils.
As of June 30, 2015, 8 laboratories are accredited for the determination of PCB in various materials (oil, water, soil), of which 3 received accreditation in the period 2014-2015.

There are no laboratories that measure PCBs in body fluids such as blood and maternal milk.
There are no existing official protocols for sampling and analysis of PCB in dielectric oils, water, soils, air, foods and body fluids.
One protocol for sampling and analysis of PCBs in dielectric oils, water, soils, air, foods and body fluids developed.

The resolution 792 of 2013 (Por la cual se adoptan los protocolos de muestreo y análisis para la determinación del contenido de PCB en aceites dieléctricos y diferentes matrices ambientales) established the national protocols for the sampling and analysis of PCBs in dielectric oils and other environmental matrixes. It is a national regulation by IDEAM.

description.narrative: PCBs in high-risk food are monitored.

comment.narrative: The Ministry of Health and Social Protection has plans to issue a norm to regulate food contaminants, which includes to set limits on PCBs.
A monitoring program on PCB in high risk food (e.g. fish, milk) has been created.
A draft agreement for the development of a monitoring program for PCB in fish products, between the Ministry of Environment and the National Institute of Food and Drug (INVIMA) was formulated.

description.narrative: Establishment of guidelines and standards for the environmentally sound management of PCBs (oil and contaminated equipment) during maintenance of equipment, transportation, storage and disposal, including occupational health and safety issues published and distributed.

comment.narrative: There is a manual for PCB management, as well as norms that establish the basic principles for proper environmentally sound management.
Technical criteria for the maintenance of equipment with dielectric oils established.

There is also an identification and description document of good practices for equipment maintenance, with such document a diagnostic process was developed in 20 companies in the sector. These documents will be included in the Manual for Sound Management of PCBs.
A new norm is planned to be established for the incinerating of PCBs.
The technical aspects that should be considered for the packing and transporting of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes are defined.

The Manual for the Sound Management of PCBs, finalized during this reporting period (2014- 2015), contains a chapter on the technical requirements for storage, packaging and transport of PCBs. The manual is currently under review by the Ministry of Environment before being published.
There are no technical guidelines for the maintenance of equipment contaminated with PCBs.
The following publications (manuals or guidelines) developed by the end of the project:
1. Guidelines for the identifying, labeling and characterization of equipment with PCBs.

The project target was met.
During this reporting period, a document (Marcado de equipos eléctricos que consisten, contienen o pueden contener PCB y desechos contaminados con PCB) collecting techniques and suppliers for PCB equipment marking and labeling, was issued by the project.
2. Manual for the registering of PCB contaminated equipment and oil stocks, for environmental authorities and PCB generators.

In addition to the document for the validation of PCB inventory information (Guide for validating the quality of information in the PCB Inventory for environmental authorities), during (2014 – 2015) a tool was developed and made available to PCB owners to support the design and planning for strategic random sampling for monitoring equipment.
3. Manual for methods to identify PCBs in soils, water, food and body fluids.
The project target was met during previous reporting period. No further activities to report on.
4. Guidelines for the selecting of PCB treatment and elimination technologies.

Manual for Sound Management of PCB is under revision due observations from the public (waste managers and PCBs owners) within a public consultation process .
Once finished this Manual will contain a specific chapter on alternative technologies for decontamination and disposal of PCBs in the country.
As of June 30, 2015 the Manual is still under review by the Ministry of Environment.
5. Guidelines for the environmentally sound management of PCB containing equipment (transport, storage, maintenance, operation, and final disposal).
The Manual for Sound Management of PCBs includes a specific chapter on storage, transportation, packaging and disposal of PCBs.
The publication of a video on PCB management.

This activity has not begun yet but it has been determined that the preparation and editing of videos of the project will be conducted with the support from the Office of Communications of the Ministry of Environment.

description.narrative: National training program on the new standards, guidelines and regulations for stakeholders involved in the handling of PCBs (maintenance companies, junk yards and recycling plants, large consumers and industries, retail consumers and industrial users among others).

comment.narrative:
There is not a structured program for the training of personnel who do maintenance on PCB contaminated equipment and their proper management.
The existing norm for PCBs establishes that for the sampling of PCB contaminated oils the personnel should be certified by the National Learning Service (SENA).
One program developed for the training and certifying of qualifications for technicians and operations personnel that do sampling of dielectric oils in equipment and also do maintenance.

Up to June 30, 2105 there are a total of 229 SENA certified technicians on sampling for determination of PCB in dielectric oils. of the 229 certified to date, 100 technicians were certified during the period 2014-2015.

description.narrative: Number of authorized operators for the management of equipment or oils containing PCBs increased.

comment.narrative: Some of the electrical companies have storage capacity for PCB contaminated equipment and oils in an environmentally safe manner, especially those that are the largest generators, commercializers and distributors. There are four companies that have storage capacity for PCB contaminated equipment and oils and which have environmental license from the corresponding authority.
An assessment to define the needs for storage, packing and transport of PCB contaminated equipment and wastes carried out.
A report was developed on current storage, packaging and transportation practices for PCBs, identified areas that need strengthening for authorized waste managers.
A program is established to strengthen the capacity of managers and environmental authorities to issue the respective environmental licenses and complete the corresponding follow up.
During the reporting period the project collected strengthening needs for waste managers, in order to formulate and implement for them the strengthening program.

description.narrative: Definition of criteria to identify, prioritize and remove from use equipment located in high risk areas, in accordance with the provisions of the Stockholm Convention.

comment.narrative: There is not a protocol and criteria established for the identifying and defining of priorities for equipment management in high risk areas.
Equipment inventory and program for the removal of PCB contaminated equipment from high risk zones has been carried out.

Up to date, there are 13 companies located in the not Interconnected Zone (NIZ) that have been registered as PCB holders and who are actively participating in the national inventory reporting of 279 units.
An additional 9 companies will participate in the NIZ pilot related on marking and identification of equipment under the project GRANT signed during the period 2014-2015 with CIDET.

description.narrative: PCB contaminated sites identified, guidelines and action plan proposed.

comment.narrative: There is not a protocol and criteria established for the identifying and managing of PCB contaminated sites.
Action plan for the environmental authorities to start an identification of contaminated sites program created.
Currently there has been a list compiled of companies and zones that will be prioritized for the identification of contaminated sites by regional environmental authorities.
Protocol and criteria developed for identifying and managing PCB contaminated sites.

This activity has not taken place yet. During the first half of 2016 there will be a document that will guide the actions to be taken by the regional environmental authorities for the identification and characterization of PCB contaminated sites.
One workshop on the presentation of the action plan with the environmental authorities personnel completed.

According to the schedule of activities defined by the project it is expected that during the second half of 2015 there will be a workshop on the action plan that the environmental authorities must develop for the identification of PCB contaminated sites.

description.narrative: Other stakeholders besides the electricity sector that have existing stocks of equipment and/or materials contaminated with PCBs with content exceeding 50 ppm have been identified and included in national inventory.

comment.narrative: The Regulation 222 established a series of criteria for the identifying, labeling and characterizing of PCB wastes. There is a PCB generator register which is administered by IDEAM. All generators of PCBs must report their stocks to this entity
A demonstration project to identify the different equipment owners of the generation, distribution, commercializing, and distribution energy companies developed.
During the period 2014 - 2015 a pilot project was formulated to educate PCB owners part of the EPSA S.A. E.S.P. company network, located in the municipality of Buenaventura - Valle del Cauca.

description.narrative: Identification (analysis, inventory) and environmentally sound management of PCBs in Non-Interconnected Areas (ZNI).

comment.narrative: In the areas that are not interconnected (ZNI) to the national electricity network there has not been an inventory done for PCB equipment and oils. Some of these equipments are found in high risk zones (ecological, protected zones, forest reserves or vulnerable populations).
Technical Assistance for the energy service providers in the ZNI for the identification of equipment and the compliance with Resolution 0222 of 2011 carried out.

Up to June 2015, 6 training and activities were held aimed at companies located in the not interconnected zones (NIZ). 2 of these sessions were conducted in the reporting period 2014-2015.
During the period 2014 -2015 a pilot program was formulated on marking and identification of equipment located in the non-interconnected zone.
In December 2015 the implementation of that pilot program will be launched with the participation of 9 companies in the NIZ.

description.narrative: Environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs through demonstration pilot project.
Agreements with PCB holders and/or waste managers to demonstrate the operation, maintenance, disposal and storage of PCBs in accordance with new standards, rules and regulations established.

comment.narrative: During equipment maintenance (transformers) cross contamination can occur.

One training program carried out with 15 maintenance companies that work with equipment that has dielectric fluids and company personnel in the electricity sector so that they are made aware of the criteria established in the Resolution 222 of 2011. This will avoid cross contamination and implement environmentally sound management of PCBs.
The draft guide for good practices in maintenance is being validated by a technical committee made up of delegates from seven companies.

It has been identified that companies that do equipment maintenance in some cases do not have sound management practice for PCB waste
There are six companies in the country that have environmental license for PCB storage, but it has been detected that they do not manage the oils contaminated with PCBs correctly.
The environmental authorities do not have the technical tools that will allow for control and monitoring of companies that have these practices.

Technical assistance program developed with six companies that service storage, packing, and transport (land and ocean) PCB contaminated equipment and oils so that these activities are completed considering the best available technology and the best environmental practices.

The Manual for Sound Management of PCBs was developed during the period 2014-2015 and includes a chapter on storage, packaging and transport of PCB, in line with BEP/BAT requirements.
A report on the strengthening of needs identified for a sample of 13 companies, managers and transporters, has also been prepared during this reporting period.

description.narrative: Partnering with interested technology servicers to evaluate alternatives for the decontamination and disposal of equipment and oils contaminated by PCBs.

comment.narrative: The country has two companies that have environmental license to manage PCBs, one for re-cleaning and the other for dechlorination with sodium. There is also a company that has three rotary incinerators for hazardous waste and where there is presently a project pilot for the eliminating of ODS. This company has declared interest in doing a pilot project for PCB elimination.

Partnerships established with at least two interested technology servicers to evaluate alternatives for the decontamination and disposal of equipment and oils contaminated by PCBs, through the following pilot projects:
There are 4 companies that export PCBs.

Pilot project for the implementation of decontamination technologies for PCB contaminated equipment and to establish environmental requirements for the control and monitoring by the environmental authorities.

During the period 2014-2015 the equipment washing pilot project was completed with LITO S.A.S.
9 pieces of waste equipment were decontaminated. It was cleaned a total of 47 MT of non-porous material (metal) and it was destined for metal recycling facilities.

Pilot project to develop testing of PCB elimination through thermal processes (rotary kiln or coprocessing in cement kiln), in order to establish the operating conditions for the use of this treatment.

During the period 2014-2015 technical and environmental assessments were carried out to select the two plants that will perform tests burn for PCB in order to determine the feasibility of using these technologies in the country.
The selected plants underwent an evaluation on to assess safety and occupational health issues.
Under the agreement signed with CEMEX, was selected a company specialized in strategic communications to design and implement a communication plan of the pilot.
A group of national and international experts is available for the design, implementation, analysis and consolidation of results.
Pilot project for the treatment of PCBs using dechlorination, plasma, catalytic oxidation or other technology.

During the period 2014-2015 the project for the installation of a semi-industrial scale plant for the disposal of PCB by oxidation was formulated.
The project will be developed by Universidad del Valle.

description.narrative: Management and disposal of as much of the PCB contaminated equipment as possible that is located in high priority areas identified in the country.

comment.narrative: The electrical service companies that are in the non connected zones in many cases are located in zones that are vulnerable from the ecological and social point of view.
PCB contaminated equipment located in the Non-Interconnected Areas that are considered to be high environmental and ecological sensitivity removed and eliminated.
During the period 2014-2015 the terms of reference for the bidding process of removal and disposal of PCB equipment were prepared.

It has been identified that in zones that are high priority ecological reserves in the Choco or the Amazonia there are PCB contaminated equipment that have been abandoned and the oil has leaked onto the soil.
600 tonnes PCB contaminated equipment and oils from the ZNI or from the owners in high ecological interest zones or high social vulnerability zones eliminated.

Currently a total of 404.1 MT of waste contaminated with PCB was exported in compliance with the formalities of the Basel Convention.
During the period 2014-2015 a Project on the identification and marking of equipment located in a non-interconnected zone was formulated, the project will determine the amount of waste and equipment to be eliminated in NIZ and the process of removal and disposal is expected to be developed during 2016.

Measurements of PCBs in breast milk and body fluid have not taken place because measurements are still required to determine whether the population that is potentially exposed presents any contamination levels.

Tests of PCBs in body fluids (blood and breast milk) carried out with a group of people who have been or are exposed to PCBs in a region or activity that is considered to be of high impact and establish a protocol for its national application by health authorities.

An agreement was prepared and signed with INS, which includes the development of a monitoring program for PCB in human milk and body fluids.
According to the schedule of agreed upon activities, sampling and analysis will take place during the period 2015-2016.
One business in the electricity sector has identified a PCB contaminated site and is aware of a site located in the Department of ChocÃ³ that is contaminated by PCB.
Monitoring of PCBs in potentially contaminated soils in a site or region that is of high priority.

Two sites potentially contaminated with PCB were identified during this reporting period.
Guidelines of PCB contaminated sites identification for environmental authorities are currently under development.
Monitoring of these sites will be conducted once the guidelines have been finished .
Identification and testing of abandoned equipment.

Abandoned electrical equipment has been reported in the municipality of Lloro - Choco . Using the project resources, the equipment will be analyzed (weight and PCB concentration) and be removed from the area and taken for proper environmental disposal.

description.narrative: Technical and environmental feasibility for each one of the technological alternatives proved and the lessons learned for their replication.

comment.narrative: The demonstrative pilot projects will have the involvement of the environmental authorities, PCB generators, treatment companies in order to guarantee that the projects can be replicated.
Technical and environmental evaluation for each of the proven alternatives, establishing lessons learned and their publication.

The final report for washing waste equipment is ready. For the other demonstration projects the final results will be incorporated in the same report, including lessons learned and opportunities for replication.

description.narrative: Monitoring, adaptive feedback, outreach and evaluation.
Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative: No documents in baseline situation.
4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year
Quarterly reports were submitted to UNDP accordance with the requirements of the institution.
1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.
The second annual report of the project will be presented this year.
1 Mid-term evaluation.
UNDP developed the terms of reference for the mid-term evaluation and int. bidding is on-going. The MTE will take place during the second half of 2015.
1 Final evaluation
The final evaluation will take place in 2017, when completing the project.
MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.
Communication and support material was shared in events, including notebooks, flyers and banners.

title.narrative: Tercera Comunicacion Nacional de Cambio Climatico

description.narrative: Colombia’s Third National Communication on Climate change to the UNFCCC

description.narrative: Colombia’s Third National Communication on Climate change to the UNFCCC

To prepare a Third National Communication document and present it to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and to the country, with coherent, transparent flexible and comparable information, considering the national circumstances of Colombia.

comment.narrative: The project counts with information generated by the First and Second National Communications and by the vulnerability and adaptation projects implemented so far.

As a non-Annex I party, Colombia seeks to share information on its GHG emissions for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010, report on the national policies to face GHG emissions, and adaptation measures to climate change adverse effects; capacity building and public awareness activities; and produce information on the country’s vulnerability to climate change and extreme weather events, to allow the country to prepare to face the impacts of climate change. This information shall reflect the limitations, problems and obstacles found in the implementation of the UNFCCC.

The Third National Communication on Climate Change project has the following consolidated progress to date: 1. New climate change scenarios for Colombia 2011-2100, as generated at the regional and departmental levels. 2. Results for the four sectors of the National Greenhouse Gasses Inventory of - 1990-2012 series (technical documents, worksheets and reporting tables). 3. Overview of mitigation actions implemented at the national level.

description.narrative: National Circumstances, updated national development priorities in the context of climate change.
National Circumstances, updated national development priorities in the context of climate change.

comment.narrative:
The project counts with information on:
a) political and geographic aspects; b) environmental offer; c) social characteristics; d) economic characteristics; e) planning and policy actions related to climate change as of year 2010.

The goal for this component is to update information for the period 2008-2014 on institutional, ecosystem, social, economic and political issues. The analysis will be made for the national and regional contexts. There will be a close look at the marine and coastal areas and the national circumstances related to extreme weather events will be described. A national and regional analysis on the national priorities for the country’s National Development Plan will be presented.

With regard to national circumstances, progress has been with the issuance of the document on national circumstances that have given way to institutional and territorial vulnerability to the effects of climate change and greenhouse gases emissions in the country.

description.narrative: National GHG inventory for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010
National GHG inventory for the years 2005, 2008 and 2010

comment.narrative: The project counts with information on GHG inventories for 1990, 1994, 2000, and 2004. The component includes five modules as determined by the 1996 IPCC guidelines: 1) Energy; 2) Industrial Processes; 3) Agriculture; 4) Land use, land use change and forestry; and 5) waste.

The goal is to calculate the GHG inventories for the years 2005, 2008, and 2010, according to the 2006 IPCC guidelines. A database will also be developed with information for each module and emission factors used.

Substantial progress has been made in this regard, as documentation has been generated and is currently available – including technical documents, worksheets and reporting tables for the 1990-2012 series of the National Greenhouse Gases Inventory. The National GHG Inventory estimated emissions by sources and removals by sinks of greenhouse gases based on the methodologies expounded in the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for the main sectors: Energy, Waste, Industrial Processes and Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use. The inventory results – in all sectors – have been validated through workshops and inter-agency working groups. In addition, quality assurance reviews have been held with international experts for some of the sectors. Data are currently being consolidated and integrated for the whole series calculated.

description.narrative: National and sectorial mitigation measures compiled and evaluated in the context of the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy
Report of information about the actions to mitigate climate change in Colombia.

comment.narrative: The project counts with information on national plans and policies related to climate change and Colombia’s participation in Clean Development Mechanisms.

The goal is to report the mitigation actions taken by the country, in regard to the implementation of the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy -CLCDS. In addition there will be a description of Colombia's participation in international carbon markets, and the development of National Appropriate Mitigation Actions - NAMAs. Finally, the progress of the REDD Strategy will be reported.

Progress on the issue of mitigation measures is included in the document of mitigation actions carried out by Colombia. The latter document reports the developments attained by these actions in the country, thereby delving into issues such as the Colombian Low Carbon Development Strategy, which covers the Sectorial Action Plans and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions, the Strategy for Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation, Colombia's participation in carbon markets, and addresses the issue of voluntary commitment on mitigation actions under the Cancun agreements.

description.narrative: Sectorial and regional vulnerability to climate change in Colombia, evaluated according to improved methodologies
Vulnerability to climate change in Colombia, evaluated according to improved methodologies.

comment.narrative: The country counts with a methodology developed by the SNC for climate change vulnerability analysis. There are climate change scenarios available, as a tool for vulnerability analyses. The project counts with the compilation of results of the various vulnerability and adaptation projects.

The TCN seeks to generate updated climate change scenarios for the period 2011-2100. Identify current and projected threats under climate change. Analyze the vulnerability to climate change with a better resolution for the natural regions of Colombia, and for water resources, glaciers and the health sector. Additionally, identify the vulnerability to climate variability and extreme events.

As for the issue of regional and sectorial vulnerability to climate change, significant progress has been made including the preparation and publication of new climate change scenarios for Colombia 2011-2100. These scenarios were generated both regionally and by departments, taking into account variables of precipitation and average temperature, and following the methodologies proposed by the IPCC. The new scenarios of climate change have been widely disseminated through printed media, digital apps, posts on IDEAM and UNDP websites, and holding events (including transmission via streaming), meetings and press releases. In addition, an analysis was conducted on the annual series for the 1981-2100 period of the multi-scenario assembly for precipitation and temperature variables, in order to represent them spatially.

description.narrative: Other information and knowledge relevant for compliance with the UNFCCC objectives
Other information and knowledge relevant for compliance with the UNFCCC objectives

comment.narrative: During the SNC a strategy on education, training and public awareness on climate change was initiated. The project counts with information on the results of this strategy. Also the project counts with additional information related to technology and financial needs for the achievement of the UNFCCC objectives.

The goal is to include additional information related to actions that the country has taken on climate change. The results obtained in the strategy on education, training and public awareness on climate change will be included, at the national, regional and sectorial levels. A summary of the country’s technology needs for adaptation and mitigation, which includes the progress on the Technology Needs Assessment (TNA).

With regard to other relevant information and knowledge for the fulfillment of the objectives of the UNFCCC in Colombia, progress has been made in the analysis of financing issues, through the progress document which includes information about Colombia’s sources, obstacles and needs in relation to funding for climate change actions, which includes global experiences on issues of financing for climate change, international methodological routes for the analysis of funding sources, and issues related to identification of (international national and regional) funding sources, investment and resources available for climate change funding in the country. Progress has also been made in the field of education, through the result analysis report in the implementation of the National Strategy for Education, Training and Public Awareness on climate change, which involves some of the work currently under way in conjunction with regional nodes of climate change, through workshops and surveys.

description.narrative: Conservación de la biodiversidad en paisajes impactados por la minería en la Región del Chocó Biogeográfico

To safeguard biodiversity in the Chocó biogeographic region from the direct impacts of gold, silver and platinum mining and indirect impacts of mining [population growth and development of agriculture, forestry, fisheries and other sectors]
Four (4) Existent protected areas (PA) under sustainable management protecting local ecosystems

comment.narrative: 47,811 ha 5 work agreements have been signed for the implementation of activities with 4 National Natural Parks (Orquideas: Asociación Colombiana de Acuicultores; Tatamá: Corpocam and Asocasan; Farallones: Amatea; Munchique: Corpohabitats) to improve their sustainable management through monitoring, control and surveillance in Tatamá NP (37.811 ha) and Farallones NP (10.000 ha)

description.narrative: Total area of protected forests (ha) by new multiple use protected areas (MUPA,) created to reduce the impacts of mining

comment.narrative: An analysis of the document "Conservation priorities for the Chocó ecoregion" was held, including extra criteria to select new protected areas initiatives, such as: Being part of the temporary reserve of natural resources, have mining pressures in the zone, include indigenous communities on its buffer zone and to be a conservation priority for the Regional System of Protected Areas from the Pacific (RSPAP). Through this analysis, two (2) initiatives were selected to promote their declaration process: Páramo del Duende and Bosques del Citará (Upper part of the Atrato basin). There is an agreement with the "Constructores de Paz" foundation to support the regional environmental authority (Codechoco) in the process of declaring the multiple use protected area (MUPA) of “Cuenca alta del río Atrato” in the department of Chocó. Through this agreement, a work plan will be set and other activities are going to be held such as the design and delimitation of the PA and the generation of the final protocol to conclude with the formal creation. In addition, processes of creation of new protected areas have been identified in the Cauca and Nariño departments, that are included in the Choco ecoregion

description.narrative: The Policy, legal and planning framework in the mining sector addresses the direct threats to biodiversity from mining operations.
Legal, political and planning tools (of national level) include environmental and social criteria to prevent/mitigate, offset and restore the impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services

comment.narrative: Legal, political and planning existing tools:a) Mining code, b) Required environmental license for the exploitation phase c) Frame for environmental impact assessment

Updated tools (legal, political and planning) with recommendations to include environmental and social criteria to prevent/mitigate, offset and restore the impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services; a) Mining code, b) Environmental licensing process, c) Guidelines for designating areas in the mining reserve.

Contributions and advice given by WWF in the design of the Strategic Environmental Assessment methodology for the mining sector, on the meeting facilitated by the Planning National Department (NPD) A document-mapping was constructed to identify different mining-environmental political, normative, and regulatory tools A document-mapping and analysis of stakeholders was constructed(Public and private organizations, Civil organizations, communities, etc.) related with mining activity in the Pacific Region.

description.narrative: Protection of biodiversity in areas highly vulnerable to the indirect effects of mining.
# of municipal planning instruments (POT) that includes the priority zones for conservation, and zoning to deal with direct and indirect impacts of mining on biodiversity and ecosystem services

comment.narrative: A general information analysis was held for the environmental, biodiversity, ecosystem services, and environmental determinants components of the Territorial Zoning Plans (POT) in the municipalities of Murindó, Vigia del Fuerte, Tado and Buenaventura. In the 9 prioritized municipalities, the advances of the POMCAS were revised. It was formulated an agreement with the IIAP to advance in the inclusion on the POT of biodiversity protection tools against mining, in the municipalities of Tado and Vigia del Fuerte. Additionally, through this agreement, the identification of direct and indirect impacts of mining and its relationship to ecosystem services in these two municipalities will be held.

A baseline was established as input for the training capacity building plan of the project. Issues such as training offer in the project area were analyzed, and also in other cities (Bogotá and Cali). Information was gathered on training needs for institutions and communities around the topics of the project . Interviews were made with entities such as the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development (MADS), Ministry of Mines and Energy (MME),the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Alexander von Humboldt Institute (IAvH), Institute of Environmental Investigations of the Pacific (IIAP), Codechocó, Bioinnova, ASOCASAN, Cocomacia and the Universities of Los Andes, Javeriana and Claretian.
A document with the available technical training offer was prepared, identifying possible partners in Universities and academic sector. The information was arranged in a matrix detailing demand information by theme and target audience.

The diagnosis of at least 200 hectares identified for restoration will take place, local capacity to implement the methodology of the protocol will be analyzed and preliminary analysis of socio-environmental viability of the areas identified restoration will take place.

description.narrative: Prevention of emissions (tCO2-e) due to rainforest deforestation

comment.narrative: An agreement with Cocomacia was formulated in order to perform a preliminary analysis of technical, economic, social and institutional feasibility of REDD + projects in the priority areas of the project. Under the agreement secondary information for socio-environmental characterization of communities that have shown interest in REDD + projects will be collected, the lessons learned from REDD + processes implemented or being implemented in the Chocó will be systematized; The social, technical and economic viability of at least 10 potential communities to implement REDD + projects is going to be preliminarily analyzed.

description.narrative: Avoided deforestation (ha) at the end of project

comment.narrative: Avoided deforestation will be reported through REDD + projects. An agreement with Cocomacia was formulated in order to perform a preliminary analysis of technical, economic, social and institutional feasibility of REDD + projects in the priority areas of the project. Under the agreement secondary information for socio-environmental characterization of communities that have shown interest in REDD + projects will be collected, the lessons learned from REDD + processes implemented or being implemented in the Chocó will be systematized; The social, technical and economic viability of at least 10 potential communities to implement REDD + projects is going to be preliminarily analyzed.

description.narrative: Number of initiatives for sustainable use of biodiversity resources being marketed

comment.narrative: Two (2) non-timber products, Naidi (Euterpe oleracea) and Jagua (American Genipa)

It was made an evaluation of the productive chains of Naidi and Jagua, finding that they are currently limited conditions for the development of these productive chains in the project areas (obtaining resource use licences and rupture of relations between suppliers and retailers) . Considering the above, an assessment of the problem is being conducted to determine ways to continue and an analysis is going on to understand the current situation in the region with respect to the marketing of non-timber forest products (NTFP) and also the identification of key actors who have been involved in the processes among which are: private actors (Ecoflora and Espavé, Bioinnova Corporation), public institutions (IIAP, Codechoco, MADS) community stakeholders (Cocomacia and Asocasan) with other projects such as the GEF Nagoya. Progress is being made in the identification and characterization of productive initiatives that are currently developed from non-timber forest products (NTFP) and has potential for generating income for communities in the Choco region, with emphasis on the areas impacted by mining. This exercise will: a) Identify NTFPs generating income for communities, b) Identify the status of the models, companies, initiatives or proposed business plans or systems implementation for NTFP, c) Identify feasibility studies and supply chains of NTFP being carried out, d) identify and characterize the NTFP harvesting protocols that exist for the Chocó e) To propose an analysis matrix, state models or business plans with variables regarding environmental, social and economic and legal sustainability.

description.narrative: Change in average annual income of members of local communities (including women and men) as a result of the sale of assai palm (Euterpe oleracea) and jagua (American Genipa)

comment.narrative: Women: X Men: X. The goal will be participatory defined on the first six months of the project

In the process of updating the management plans, productive activities aimed at improving family income will be included. For this, a baseline will be made for families to be included in these processes. At the same time a strategy will be designed to include a gender perspective in these activities and thus to ensure equality between men and women. For this, it is important to consider the roles of men and women within their communities and organizations, so that we can empower them and contribute to equitable development of families and communities. A gender strategy will also be included in the training program, linked with the other components of the project.

description.narrative: Uso sostenible y conservación de la biodiversidad (BD) en bosques secos para garantizar el flujo de los servicios ecosistémicos

Uso sostenible y conservación de la biodiversidad en bosques secos para garantizar el flujo de los servicios ecosistémicos y mitigar procesos de deforestación y desertificación en la región del Caribe y el Valle Interandino del río Magdalena.

To reduce the current trend of dry forest deforestation and desertification processes and ensure the flow of multiple global ecosystem services through biodiversity conservation, sustainable land management, and carbon storage.
Coverage (in hectares) of dry forest and other dry ecosystems in protected areas and/or under conservation agreements.

comment.narrative:
A) 30,182.5 ha identified as potential areas for protection and conservation (PAs/CAs) in the following prioritized basins:
- 7,198 ha, Cañas-Ancho River (Dibulla)
- 7,698 ha Garupal River (Valledupar)
- 6,499.5 ha, Arroyo Grande River (San Juan Nepomuceno)
- 2,770 ha, Aipe-Patá River (Aipe-Neiva)
- 3,150 ha Yaví River (Natagaima-Prado)
- 2,867 ha, Dagua River (Dagua, La Cumbre, Restrepo and Vijes)
B) One (1) “letter of intention aimed at consolidating the agreement or declaration of conservation areas and sustainable use of the dry forest ecosystem by referendum", signed on June 16, 2015 by representatives of the community action boards of the municipalities of Aipe and Neiva which belong to the basin of the Aipe and Patá Rivers; these areas of influence of the project cover 9,107 ha and conform a landscape matrix which is essential for the conservation, restauration, rehabilitation and sustainable use and the improvement of the dry forest's ecological connectivity and functionality.

description.narrative: “Carbon units not released (as a global benefit) by the end of the project”.

comment.narrative: Carbon units are being recalculated with technical support from the IDEAM (Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies), based on the dry forest cartography mapped by this institute in 2013 and the corresponding calculation methodology. According to this calculation, the goal of 93,700 tCO2 is susceptible to changes which will be promptly reported once the information is delivered by the IDEAM. Additionally, the project held consultations with the Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development and the IDEAM regarding the indicator proposed by the project: Identified carbon units with capacity of commercialization in the carbon market as of the end of the project. In this regard, the recommendation is not to address the commercialization in the voluntary carbon market but to link this indicator and its goal to the national priorities. In this sense, it is expected that the indicator will be modified as follows: Carbon units not released (as a global benefit) by the end of the project.

description.narrative: Strengthened implementation of the regulatory and land use planning framework facilitates the reduction of dry ecosystem deforestation and desertification processes.
Number of local plans that incorporate strategies of conservation of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management.

comment.narrative: Regional planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or four-year action plans of the Autonomous Regional Corporations (CARs) and/or the environmental determinants of the CARs: 0
Planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or CAR four-year action plans and/or CAR environmental determinants: 12

Progress achieved in the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) conservation strategies into planning relates to processes of change of land use plans (second generation) that are currently conducted by the municipalities as well as changes on regulatory tools related to environmental guidelines and determinants for land use currently conducted by the CARs:
A) One (1) document of diagnosis and technical assessment of the environmental component for the 6 municipalities in the work area: Natagaima, Aipe, Dagua (Andean region) and Dibulla, San Juan Nepomuceno and Valledupar (Caribbean region).
B) 3 technical documents prepared with recommendations (municipalities of Dibulla, Natagaima and Valledupar) for the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) in the land use plans.
C) 2 technical documents sent to the municipalities of Dibulla, Natagaima and Valledupar with recommendations for the incorporation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM) in the land use plans.
D) 6 technical meetings with the municipalities of: Natagaima, Dibulla, Valledupar, San Juan Nepomuceno, Aipe, Dagua to include dry forest and sustainable land management in land use plans.
E) One (1) land use plan (Valledupar) incorporates protection of primary forests (including dry forest) and high stubbles to land use. Valledupar's Municipal Council Agreement No. 011 from 5-June-2015
F) 4 technical meetings conducted to review environmental determinants (Cortolima, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar, CAM).
G) 4 documents prepared and sent with recommendations of incorporation of dry forest in environmental guidelines and determinants for land use: Cortolima, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar and Cardique.
H) 2 resolutions from the CARs adopting dry forest as an environmental guideline for land use: Cortolima (Resolution 560 of 20-March-2015) and Corpocesar (Resolution 0674 of 18-June-2015)
I) Elaboration of chapter 2.4: Sustainable Development and Environmental Management? in the UNDP-DNP(National Planning Department) paper called "Orientaciones para la construcción de programas de gobierno: Guía para candidatos, candidatas y ciudadanía - Elecciones de autoridades locales 2015” [Guidelines for the construction of government programs: A guide for candidates and citizens - Local Authority Election 2015]. Due to changes in the administration, the development of the second generation of the land use plan progresses very slowly; this is the reason why the project will have an influence upon other planning tools such as the CAR four-year action plans and the CAR environmental determinants on land use. In this sense, it is expected that the goal will be modified as follows: 12 planning tools (land use plan and/or municipal development plan and/or CAR four-year action plans of and/or CAR environmental determinants include strategies of conservation of biodiversity (BD), sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM).

1) The following actions have been undertaken to implement GIS tools to guide local and regional authorities in planning processes and environmental follow-up and monitoring:
A) 6 computers with installed ArcGis license delivered to the CARs as part of the strengthening of Geographic Information Systems to guide processes of planning and for the follow-up and monitoring of biodiversity, sustainable forest management and sustainable land management (REDD+).
2) The following training has been conducted related to education programs for government officers and social organizations:
A) 6 training/induction meetings with CAR officers on the handling of GIS tools and computers delivered by the project. A total of 14 officers trained, 10 men and 4 women.
B) 6 training workshops on addressing methodologies for the declaration of protected areas and/or conservation agreements and the implementation of landscape management tools. A total of 127 officers trained, 74 men and 53 women.

description.narrative:
Changes in the institutional capacity of CARs based on the UNDP sheet of assessment of capacity development:
a. Participation capacity
b. Capacity of generation, access and usage of information and knowledge.
c. Capacity of development of strategies, policies and legislation.
d. Capacity of management and implementation.
e. Capacity of monitoring and evaluation.

comment.narrative:
The following actions have been conducted as part of the CAR capacity assessment:
A) 6 UNDP capacity assessment forms sent to CARs to be completed: CVC, CAM, Corpoguajira, Cortolima, Corpocesar and Cardique.
B) 5 capacity assessment forms filled by CARs and reviewed: CVC, CAM, Corpoguajira, Corpocesar and Cardique. Results show that the CARs require substantial strengthening in terms of the handling of GIS tools for environmental planning and for environmental follow-up and monitoring within their jurisdictions. Similarly, the CARs continue to show capacity weaknesses in terms of generation, access and use of information.
